abstract.text: This chapter describes parameters and arguments for generic types, functions, and initializers. When you declare a generic type, function, subscript, or initializer, you specify the type parameters that the generic type, function, or initializer can work with. These type parameters act as placeholders that are replaced by actual concrete type arguments when an instance of a generic type is created or a generic function or initializer is called.

inlineContent.text: For an overview of generics in Swift, see

specifies that a type parameter inherits from a specific class or conforms to a protocol or protocol composition. For example, in the generic function below, the generic parameter
indicates that any type argument substituted for the type parameter

code: func simpleMax<T: Comparable>(_ x: T, _ y: T) -> T {

inlineContent.text: , for example, both conform to the

protocol, this function accepts arguments of either type. In contrast with generic types, you don’t specify a generic argument clause when you use a generic function or initializer. The type arguments are instead inferred from the type of the arguments passed to the function or initializer.

code: simpleMax(17, 42) // T is inferred to be Int
simpleMax(3.14159, 2.71828) // T is inferred to be Double

inlineContent.text: You can specify additional requirements on type parameters and their associated types by including a generic
clause right before the opening curly brace of a type or function’s body. A generic
keyword, followed by a comma-separated list of one or more

and so on), you can use it to provide more complex constraints on type parameters and their associated types. For example, you can constrain the associated types of type parameters to conform to protocols. For example,

You can also specify the requirement that two types be identical, using the

inlineContent.code: <S1: Sequence, S2: Sequence> where S1.Iterator.Element == S2.Iterator.Element

inlineContent.text: protocol and that the elements of both sequences must be of the same type.
Any type argument substituted for a type parameter must meet all the constraints and requirements placed on the type parameter.
clause can appear as part of a declaration that includes type parameters, or as part of a declaration that’s nested inside of a declaration that includes type parameters. The generic
clause for a nested declaration can still refer to the type parameters of the enclosing declaration; however, the requirements from that
clause apply only to the declaration where it’s written.
If the enclosing declaration also has a
clause, the requirements from both clauses are combined. In the example below,

code: func startsWithZero() -> Bool where Element: Numeric {

inlineContent.text: You can overload a generic function or initializer by providing different constraints, requirements, or both on the type parameters. When you call an overloaded generic function or initializer, the compiler uses these constraints to resolve which overloaded function or initializer to invoke.

inlineContent.text: specifies the type arguments of a generic type. A generic argument clause is enclosed in angle brackets (<>) and has the following form:
is a comma-separated list of type arguments. A

is the name of an actual concrete type that replaces a corresponding type parameter in the generic parameter clause of a generic type. The result is a specialized version of that generic type. The example below shows a simplified version of the Swift standard library’s generic dictionary type.

code: struct Dictionary<Key: Hashable, Value>: Collection, ExpressibleByDictionaryLiteral {

inlineContent.text: The specialized version of the generic

clause. In the example above, the
type parameter is constrained to conform to the

You can also replace a type parameter with a type argument that’s itself a specialized version of a generic type (provided it satisfies the appropriate constraints and requirements). For example, you can replace the type parameter
with a specialized version of an array,
, to form an array whose elements are themselves arrays of integers.
, you don’t use a generic argument clause to specify the type arguments of a generic function or initializer.

abstract.text: enables you to write flexible, reusable functions and types that can work with any type, subject to requirements that you define. You can write code that avoids duplication and expresses its intent in a clear, abstracted manner.
In Swift, there are two kinds of types: named types and compound types. A
is a type that can be given a particular name when it’s defined. Named types include classes, structures, enumerations, and protocols. For example, instances of a user-defined class named
have the type
. In addition to user-defined named types, the Swift standard library defines many commonly used named types, including those that represent arrays, dictionaries, and optional values.
There are two kinds of attributes in Swift—those that apply to declarations and those that apply to types. An attribute provides additional information about the declaration or type. For example, the
attribute on a function declaration indicates that, although the function returns a value, the compiler shouldn’t generate a warning if the return value is unused.
A
represents the structure of a single value or a composite value. For example, the structure of a tuple

is a comma-separated list of two elements. Because patterns represent the structure of a value rather than any one particular value, you can match them with a variety of values. For instance, the pattern
matches the tuple
and any other two-element tuple. In addition to matching a pattern with a value, you can extract part or all of a composite value and bind each part to a constant or variable name.
The

of Swift describes what sequence of characters form valid tokens of the language. These valid tokens form the lowest-level building blocks of the language and are used to describe the rest of the language in subsequent chapters. A token consists of an identifier, keyword, punctuation, literal, or operator.

In Swift, there are four kinds of expressions: prefix expressions, infix expressions, primary expressions, and postfix expressions. Evaluating an expression returns a value, causes a side effect, or both.
A

introduces a new name or construct into your program. For example, you use declarations to introduce functions and methods, to introduce variables and constants, and to define enumeration, structure, class, and protocol types. You can also use a declaration to extend the behavior of an existing named type and to import symbols into your program that are declared elsewhere.

This part of the book describes the formal grammar of the Swift programming language. The grammar described here is intended to help you understand the language in more detail, rather than to allow you to directly implement a parser or compiler.

In Swift, there are three kinds of statements: simple statements, compiler control statements, and control flow statements. Simple statements are the most common and consist of either an expression or a declaration. Compiler control statements allow the program to change aspects of the compiler’s behavior and include a conditional compilation block and a line control statement.
